abstracts.cdata!:
Both loans that were approved for the
            Philippines in 2010, were the Food Crisis Response
            Development Policy Operation and the Supplemental Support
            for Post-Typhoon Recovery. They both resulted with a
            satisfactory outcome by both the Bank and borrower. The
            reasons for the loans were the sharp spike in global prices
            of rice followed by large purchase by the National Food
            Authority leaving the Philippines among one of the hardest
            countries to be hit in the region. Also in 2009 they
            experienced two major typhoons just weeks apart that caused
            substantial losses and damage in some of the countrys most
            economically vibrant regions. Some of the key lessons
            learned from the Development Policy Operation (DPO) were a
            pre-existing government or country owned agenda is critical
            to the effectiveness of the DPO. Also there are important
            potential synergies between DPOs and Specific Investment
            Loans (SIL) that can be exploited during program implements.
            Finally, that there is potential to leverage reforms in one
            sector, such as social protection to achieve reforms in
            another, such as agricultural reform.
